Bichiko wants to open a market and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables him to get a loan of 5000 GEL. With the received credit he will open a market and will have stable income. His wife also will help him to run the business.

loans.use: to open a new food market and generate a stable income for his family

loans.name: Rahila

texts.en: Rahila is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Sabon grain Kuzuntu Village. Rahila  joined Babban Gona to create a better life for her children. In the past, Rahila suffered from poor yields that crippled her ability to feed her family and children. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Rahila will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help her earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see her increase her household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Rahila now has the opportunity to increase her yields and income and use her additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase her maize yields

loans.name: Frit B

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “PADRE URRACA”; el socio  Frit B continua dedicándose al negocio de carpintería, el socio agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado, él socio continua elaborando  diferentes tipos de trabajos como camas, muebles entre otros, siendo de esta manera que el socio saca adelante a su familia.
EL socio solicita el préstamo para la compra de madera entre otros.
texts.en:
The member, Frit B, belongs to Padre Urraca Communal Bank and still works in his carpentry business making beds, furniture, and other items.  This is how he gets his family ahead.

Frit B is requesting the loan to buy wood and other supplies.

He's grateful for this loan and also promises to make his payments by the stipulated deadline.

loans.use: to buy wood and other supplies

loans.name: Fernando

texts.pt:
O senhor Fernando é solteiro, vive com os pais e mais uma pessoa  na sua responsabilidade que é o sobrinho.
Com o dinheiro do emprestimo quer pagar despesas de legalização do espaço para a postorior reunir material para a construção da sua própria residencia
O seu sonho é ter uma casa propria, casar e constituir uma família. 
O seu principal desafio é trabalhar no sentido de criar condições para alcançar os seus objectivos, pelo que ira reembolsar o empréstimo sem entrar em mora de forma a poder se beneficiar de outros
texts.en:
Fernando is single. He lives with his parents and his nephew, who is under his care.

With the money from the loan, he wants to purchase the title to a piece of land, where he will build his own home after getting the materials he needs.

His dream is to have his own home, get married and start a family.

His main challenge is to work in order to guarantee the right conditions to achieve his goals. He will pay back the loan without defaulting, in order to receive other loans in the future.

loans.use: to purchase the title to his land.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, Omo soap, oils, etc.

loans.name: Eliezer Group

texts.fr: Madi est une femme d’affaires, membre du groupe de crédits «Eliezer», cliente de l’IMF Hekima, mariée à un infirmier, âgée de 33 ans mère de 3 enfants tous scolarisés. Elle est vendeuse des divers produits pharmaceutiques dans la ville depuis 6 ans. Elle commença son business avec de fonds de reçu de son mari. Elle va acheter des antibiotiques, pommades de massage, seringues, sérum, des anti- inflammatoires, etc. Elle souhaite accroitre et scolariser ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie Hekima pour le soutien apporté aux entrepreneurs non bancables.
texts.en: Madi is a businesswoman, member of the "Eliezer" credit group and client of the Hekima MFI. She is married to a nurse, 33 years old and mother of 3 children who all attend school. She sells various pharmaceutical products in town, for six years now. She started her business with funds received from her husband. She is going to purchase antibiotics, massage ointments, syringes, serum, anti-inflammatories, etc. She hopes to grow and school her children. In conclusion, she thanks Hekima for their support to financially excluded entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to buy antibiotics, massage ointments, syringes, serum, anti-inflammatories, etc.

loans.name: Los Invencibles Group

texts.es:
Katherin es un joven mujer de 20 años de edad, soltera, tiene un hijo de 2 años de edad, y su negocio es la venta de gaseosas.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, buena oyente, solidaria, fuerte, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla en el barrio ‘Virgen del Lujan’ área céntrica que alberga a la mayor parte de oficinas comerciales y públicas. De clima cálido sub tropical con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 21-35 grados centígrados.
Katherin es de tez morena, ojos pardos, baja estatura, cabello negro largo lo usa amarrado, complexión física mediana, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (la segunda de la derecha, viste calza rosa y blusa a rayas negras horizontales). Su vida la comparte con su hijo que aún no se encuentra en edad escolar. Viven en un humilde cuarto cercado por frágiles paredes de barro y techo cubierto por viejas tejas con piso de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. El sueño por darle un futuro mejor a su hijo la llevó a formar una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de pescado, cerrajería, tejido de ropa de bebé, panadería, venta de fruta, venta de fideo, reparación tv color y venta de pollo, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus actividades. Su negocio es la venta de gaseosas. Los quehaceres inician muy temprano por la mañana para disfrutar el aire fresco matutino e iniciar las primeras ventas; debajo de una sombrilla y al aire libre inicia su negocio diario, “vendo refresco al paso y al hielo, los clientes me pagan un par de monedas y se van…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que el clima cálido del lugar hace que las ventas sean continuas, la desventaja es la falta de dinero para la compra de sombrillas y bancos para sentarse. Su sueño es abrir un puesto de venta fijo, ella desea mejorar su negocio mediante la compra de un par de sombrillas para cubrirse del sol, sillas y refrescos. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 3 años que desarrolla esta actividad de forma independiente.
Es por esos motivos que Katherin solicita un préstamo para la compra de sombrillas, sillas y refrescos para abrir un puesto de venta fijo.
texts.en:
20-year-old Katherin is a young, single woman. She has a 2-year-old son. She sells sodas.

She is a good mother, a good listener, and an enterprising, supportive, strong, responsible and hardworking woman. Her business is located in the “Virgen del Lujan” neighborhood, located in the center, with many commercial and public establishments. It has subtropical weather and a temperature that ranges between 21 and 35 degrees Celsius.

Katherin has a dark complexion and brown eyes. She is short and has long black hair tied back. She is medium size and her mother tongue is Guaraní. She speaks it at home and speaks Spanish due to cultural and professional reasons. She is the second one standing from right to left, and is wearing pink stockings and a shirt with horizontal stripes.

She shares her life with a son who is not of school age yet. They live in a humble room guarded by fragile mud walls, a roof covered with old tiles and brick floor. It is served with potable water, electricity and sewage. She dreams of offering her son a better future, so she started a communal bank with members that work selling fish, as locksmiths, making baby clothes, as bakers, selling fruits, selling noodles, repairing TV sets and selling chicken, in order to apply for a loan to improve their businesses.

She works selling sodas. She starts very early in the morning to enjoy the fresh morning air and make her first sales. She works every day under an umbrella located outdoors. “I sell sodas at room temperature and also ice-cold. My customers give me some coins and then leave,” she says. The advantage she has is that under the hot weather, sales are continuous. The disadvantage is that she lacks the money to buy umbrellas and chairs to sit on.

Her dream is to offer her customers a place where they can stay. She would like to improve her business by buying a couple of umbrellas to offer her customers protection from the sun, chairs and beverages. This is her first loan with the institution in three years of being an independent businesswoman.

These are the reasons why Katherin is requesting a loan to buy umbrellas, chairs, and beverages to offer her customers a place where they can stay.

loans.use: to buy umbrellas, chairs and beverages.

loans.name: Harun Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
This group of 5 women hail from Dahod, India. They are led by Mumtajben who is standing in the center. Mumtajben is a 32-year-old mother of 4 children. She manages the children single headedly as she is a widow. The household income is INR 10,000 which is insufficient to meet household expenses and pay for the children's education. The monthly savings are just INR 2,000. 

Hence Mumtajben thought of starting her business to supplement the family income. She started her variety store which includes bangles, earrings, necklace etc. With this business she is currently earning INR 5,000. But she wants to earn more to support her children's education. Hence she came up with the idea to avail herself of a loan to expand her business. 

She got together with 4 other women who share similar interests. The other women are determined to help their families and want to expand their existing business. These families on average earn INR 10,000 a month out of which they are able to save only INR 2,000. 

Similar to Mumtajben, Zahedabibi is into selling bangles, earrings, necklace etc. She will use the loan to expand her variety store and earn more income. Nilofar, Nargisbanu and Rehana are into selling garments. They sell sarees, blouses, dupattas, leggings etc. and they will use the loan to expand their garments businesses. 

Together the group seeks a loan of INR 70,000. Your loan will help these women earn more and give a good education to their children. It will also pave way for a good standard of living and happiness among these families.

loans.use: To expand a retail jewelry store

loans.name: 18 De Marzo Group

texts.es:
Laritza es una mujer de 21 años de edad, soltera, tiene 2 hijos de 1 y 6 años, y su negocio es la sastrería.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, independiente, constante, optimista, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla en la zona ‘plan 3000’; sitio caracterizado por el creciente desarrollo del comercio y la manufactura en todas las áreas. Formado por colonias de tribus guarayos, campesinos del occidente y mineros relocalizados. De clima cálido sub tropical con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 22-32 grados centígrados.
Laritza es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo usa amarrado por detrás, baja estatura, complexión física delgada, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (de pie a la derecha, viste polera rosada y pantalón negro). Su vida la realiza en casa de sus familiares que trabajan, viven en un cuarto propio construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Su anhelo de superación la impulsó a liderar una banca de personas con negocios como; confección de tejidos, venta de pescado, servicio de construcción, venta de empanadas, comercio de cosméticos, venta de ropa de temporada y tejido a máquina, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus negocios. Su negocio es la sastrería; el procedimiento que realiza inicia a través de una entrevista con el cliente, donde seleccionan el diseño, se realiza la toma de medidas, realiza los moldes y procede a cortar. Una vez armado se ajustan los detalles, y se realiza la entrega de la prenda, "realizamos todo tipo de trabajo, arreglos de largos, anchos y confecciones también…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con una cartera de clientes establecida, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de una máquina de coser industrial. Su sueño es abrir una tienda para vender sus confecciones, ella desea ampliar su negocio mediante la compra de una máquina de coser industrial para la confección de ropa variada. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 3 años que se dedica a esta actividad. 
Es por esos motivos que Laritza solicita un préstamo para la compra de una máquina de coser industrial para la confección de ropa variada y con los beneficios alimentar a sus bebés.
texts.en:
Laritza is a 21-year-old, single woman who has 2 children who are 1 and 6 years old.  Her business is tailoring.  She is a good mother, enterprising, independent, persevering, optimistic, responsible and very hardworking.  She is developing her business in the “Plan 3000” zone; an area characterized by growing development in commerce and manufacturing in all areas.  It is made up of communities of the guarayo tribes, farmers from the west and relocated miners.  It has a warm, subtropical climate with a temperature that varies between 22 and 32 degrees Centigrade (71 and 90 degrees Fahrenheit) during the day.

Laritza has a dark complexion, brown eyes and long black hair that she wears tied at the back.  She is of short statures and has a thin build.  Her mother tongue is Guaraní which she speaks with her family and she speaks Spanish in the general culture and in business.  She is standing on the right, wearing a pink t-shirt and black pants.  She lives in the house of her relatives that work; they live in a small flat built of brick and cement with a corrugated iron roof and brick floor that has potable water, electricity and a sewage system.

Her desire to get ahead drove her to lead a group of people with businesses like making knitted items, selling fish, construction services, selling empanadas, selling cosmetics, selling seasonal clothing, and making loom-woven items, in order to request a loan and improve their businesses.  Her business is tailoring; the process that she carries out begins with an interview with the client where they select the design, she takes measurements, makes the pattern and proceeds to cut.  Once assembled the details are adjusted and she delivers the garment.  “We do all kinds of work, adjusting lengths and widths and making clothing, too,” she says.  The advantage of her business is that she has a group of established customers; the disadvantage is the lack of capital to purchase of an industrial sewing machine. 

Her dream is to open a shop to sell her clothing.  She wants to expand her business through the purchase of an industrial sewing machine to make various items of clothing.  This is her first loan sequence with the institution in the 3 years that she has been working in this business.  For these reasons Laritza is requesting a loan to purchase of an industrial sewing machine: to make various clothing and with the profits feed her children.

loans.use: to purchase an industrial sewing machine to make assorted clothing and feed her children with the profits.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase flour, oils, batteries, OMO washing powder, etc

loans.name: 3 De Mayo Group

texts.es:
Sobeida es una mujer de 30 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene tres hijos de diez, siete y cuatro años de edad, y su negocio es la venta de fruta.
Ella es buena madre, generosa, amable, abnegada, buena mujer, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona de ‘El Torno’ ubicado a 32 kilómetros al suroeste, es una de las ciudades intermedias más importantes, Sus calles lucen completamente pavimentadas con modernas construcciones habitacionales que se levantan en ambos lados de la moderna carretera doble vía, por donde cruzan los viajeros hacia el interior del país. De clima cálido sub tropical con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 21-35 grados centígrados. Sobeida es de tez trigueña, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo usa amarrado por detrás de la cabeza, estatura alta, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el guaraní que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (sentada, lleva un bolsón color verde lechuga). Su vida la realiza junto a su pareja que trabaja como transportista y con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela. Sus deseos de superación la impulsaron a liderar una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de cubiertas de celulares, venta de hoja de coca, venta de jugo de quinua, venta de chompas de alpaca, venta de polleras, venta de perfumes, venta de refrescos, servicio de limpieza, venta de polleras y venta de helado, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus actividades. Su negocio es la venta de fruta como; mandarina, naranja, lima, toronja y limón, que son las que se producen en el lugar. Por las mañanas acompañada en el taxi de su esposo, se dirigen a repartir la fruta a diferentes lugares como; tiendas de barrio, jugueras, restaurantes, y otros clientes, por la tarde carga su carrito de dos ruedas y se pasea por lugares comerciales vendiendo por menor y a detalle. La fruta es muy consumida por la mayoría de la población haciendo de su actividad un negocio rentable, “la fruta se vende a diario, en la época de invierno escasea y suben los precios...” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que las ventas son diarias, la desventaja es la falta de capital para el comercio mayorista. Su sueño es vender fruta por mayor, ella desea realizar la compra de fruta por mayor para estabilizar su negocio. Esta es la 3 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en dos años que lleva con esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Sobeida solicita un préstamo para la compra de fruta por mayor para estabilizar su negocio y vender por mayor.
texts.en:
Sobeida, 30, lives with her partner and has three children ages ten, seven, and four. Her business is selling fruit.

She is a good mother, generous, kind, selfless, a good woman, responsible and very hardworking. She runs her business the area of 'El Torno' located 32 kilometers southwest. It is one of the most important medium-sized cities; its streets are completely paved and there are modern residential buildings that rise on both sides of the modern two-way highway, where travelers pass on their way to the countryside. 

The area has a hot, subtropical climate with a temperature that varies during the day between 21 and 35 degrees Celsius. Sobeida has a dark complexion, brown eyes, long black hair that she wears tied in the back. She is tall and has a robust physique. Her mother tongue is Guaraní, which is spoken locally, and she speaks Spanish as part of her general knowledge and for her business (she is seated, holding a light-green bag).

She lives her life with her partner, who works as a taxi driver, and their children, who go to school. Her desire to excel prompted her to lead a communal banking group of people with businesses such as sales of cell-phone covers, sales of coca leaf, sales of quinoa juice, sales of alpaca sweaters, sales of skirts, sales of perfumes, sales of soft drinks, cleaning, and sales of ice cream, in order to request loans and improve their activities. Her business is selling fruit such as mandarin oranges, oranges, limes, grapefruit, and lemons, which are the types of fruits produced in the area. In the morning she and her husband use his taxi to deliver the fruit different places such as convenience stores, juicing stands, restaurants, and other customers. In the afternoon she pushes her two-wheeled cart past commercial areas selling fruit in small portions at retail. The fruit is consumed by most people, making her business a profitable activity. "The fruit is sold daily; in the winter time it is scarce and prices go up ..." she says. The advantage of her business is that she sells daily; the disadvantage is the lack of capital for wholesale trade. Her dream is to sell wholesale fruit; she wants to buy fruit at wholesale to stabilize her business. This is the third round of loans in the two years that they have been with the institution.

It is for these reasons that Sobeida is requesting a loan to purchase wholesale fruit to stabilize her business and sell at wholesale.

loans.use: to purchase wholesale fruit to stabilize her business and sell at wholesale.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “PADRE URRACA”; la socia Dominga alterna sus actividades diarias dedicandose al negocio de venta de autopartes de autos como parabrisas, faros entre otros, la socia agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de faros entre otros.
texts.en: The member belongs to the “PADRE URRACA” communal bank. Dominga combines her daily activities with working in her business selling auto parts like windshield wipers and headlights amongst others.The member is grateful for the loan and at the same time promises to pay the installments within the stipulated time. She has been in this business for a long time and things are going well thanks to the determination she brings to her work each day, this being the way she gets her family ahead. Dominga is requesting the loan to buy headlights amongst others.

loans.use: to buy headlights amongst others.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov, a 43-year-old lady living with two children and her husband, earns a living by farming in Vattanak village. Spending day and night taking care of her children and business, she wants to have a comfortable life. 

Currently, she is keeping on with the farming while her oldest son earns extra money by fishing. 

Pov has difficulty in using a battery for home energy. She needs to recharge the battery every week. Seeing the difficulty of using a car battery, Pov decided to apply for a Kiva loan to buy solar home energy. She believes solar home energy can enhance her lifestyle to a comfortable condition.

loans.use: to pay for a solar home system

location.town: Vattanak Village, Vattanak Commune, Sambo District

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.fr: Anto est une femme d’affaires, conseillère du groupe de crédits «Tusaidiane», cliente de l’IMF Hekima, veuve, âgée de 45 ans, mère de 7 enfants tous étudient. Elle est vendeuse des braises dans un dépôt à son domicile depuis 15 ans. Elle commença son business avec de fonds reçu de son mari, lors de son vivant. Elle va s’approvisionner en 5 sacs de braises. Elle souhaite accroitre son activité, scolariser et nourrir ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie Hekima pour le soutien apporté aux entrepreneurs non bancables.
texts.en: Anto is a businesswoman and an advisor from the Tusaidiane credit group, a client of IMF Hekima. She is a 45-year-old widowed mother to seven children, all of whom are currently receiving educations. She has been selling charcoal out of her own home for the past 15 years. She started this business with funds given to her by her husband while he was still alive. She will purchase five sacks of charcoal. She hopes to be able to increase her capital and make sure her children are educated and well-fed. Finally, she would like to thank Hekima for the support they give to entrepreneurs excluded from the traditional banking system.

loans.use: to purchase five sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is a married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Rowena is 45 years old, and one of her children is currently in school.

Rowena has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. Rowena requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

Rowena has been in this business for 11 years. Rowena would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
As a parent of six children, Carmelita works hard to support her family.

She has a food-vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling rice. Carmelita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-vending business.

Carmelita has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Phet

texts.en:
Phet is a craftsman living in Vattanak Village with his wife and two children. He works on crafting houses' equipment such as doors, windows, tables, etc. Crafting takes Phet a long time to finish products; therefore, he is working till night on his daily activities. However, his current energy source (car battery) is not reliable. It has a short life span and is easily damaged. Sometimes, the car battery runs out during his working time, which forces him to stop his activity at night. 

After getting a good recommendation from a neighbor who uses a solar home system, Phet decided to apply for a Kiva loan to buy a solar home system. He believes this decision will improve his energy to run his business and also save on utility fees.

loans.use: to pay for a solar home system

location.town: Vattanak Village, Vattanak Commune, Sambo District

loans.name: Jérusalem Group

texts.fr: Musienene est commerçante, membre de la banque communautaire «Jérusalem», cliente de l’IMF Hekima, âgée de 43 ans, mariée, mère 3 enfants scolarisés. Elle est vendeuse des souliers sur un étalage dans la rue animée de la ville depuis 10ans. Elle commença son business avec de fonds reçu de son mari. Pour accroitre son activité, elle va acheter 20 paires de souliers. Elle souhaite scolariser et nourrir ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie Hekima pour le soutien apporté aux entrepreneurs non bancables.
texts.en: Musienene is a shopkeeper and a member of the Jérusalem community bank, a client of IMF Hekima. She is a 43-year-old married mother to three children, all of whom are currently receiving an education. She has been selling shoes from her own stall on a lively city street for the past 10 years. She started this business with funds given to her by her husband. In order to grow her activity, she wants to purchase 20 pairs of shoes. She hopes to be able to make sure her children are educated and well-fed. Finally, she would like to thank Hekima for the support they give to entrepreneurs excluded from the traditional banking system.

loans.use: to purchase 20 pairs of shoes

loans.name: Doeun

texts.en:
Doeun, a house builder for almost 15 years, lives in Vattanak village with his wife and three children, two of whom work as farmers.  

He wants to save time and money to improve the family's conditions; however, a car battery won't allow him. He has to spend time going to charge the battery at the battery station every two or three days and spend $0.50 every time, which consumes not only his time but also money. 

After he found out the benefit of a solar home system, Doeun decided to apply for a Kiva loan to buy a solar home system to achieve his goal. He believes a solar system can help him save time and money, and also improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for a solar home system

location.town: Vattanak Village, Vattanak Commune, Sambo District

loans.name: Anahis

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “PADRE URRACA”; la socia Anahis continua con el negocio de venta de autopartes de autos como parabrisas, faros entre otros, la socia agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado, la socia es una persona responsable  y empeñosa, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de faros entre otros.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the Padre Urraca communal bank.  The member, Anahis, continues with the business of selling auto parts like windshields and headlights, among others.

The member is grateful for the loan given through these means.  She pledges to make her payments according to the schedule.  Anahis is a responsible and diligent person.  Being this way she gets her family ahead.

Anahis is requesting the loan to buy headlights and other items.

loans.use: to buy headlights and other items.

loans.name: Rodita

texts.en:
Rodita is grateful that she was granted a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy dressed chickens needed in her food business. Through her earnings she is able to support her family and meet their daily basic needs. Aside from her food stall she also has a Smart-Padala business (small money remittance through mobile cellular phones).

Now she would like  to apply for a 15,000 PHP loan that she will use to buy dozens of dressed chickens and partly to pay for some working capital for her money remittance business. She is thanking God and you in advance for a good return on her investment and the financial help that will be given her. Rodita dreams that all her hard work will bear fruit to give her family a bright future and be able to send her children to the best schools. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more dressed chickens needed in her business and partly for small remittance business.

loans.name: Felyn

texts.en: Felyn is 32 years old and married with one child in school, Felyn works very hard to provide for them. For four years, she has operated a general store in the Philippines. Felyn requested a 12,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation to buy items to sell in her store such as canned goods, beverages, home care products, and groceries. In the future, Felyn would like to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her store

loans.name: Lorlyn

texts.en: Lorlyn works hard to support her family. Lorlyn is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines, which she has been operating for three years. Lorlyn requested a 23,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell to her customers. Lorlyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is 45 years old and is married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her store, such as canned goods, personal care products, and other groceries.

Florita has previously borrowed and repaid 3 loans from NWTF. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns income from a manicure and pedicure business.

Florita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Ariza Joy

texts.en:
Ariza Joy is 25 years old, and married with one child who is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ariza Joy has a rice retailing business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more stock of rice to sell.

Ariza Joy has been in this business for five years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice to sell.

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Shirly is 41 years old and has one child, who is currently in school.

Shirly has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested an 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Shirly has been in this business for 20 years, and she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 30 years old and married. She has a general store in the Philippines and requested an 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

Marites has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items, such as canned good, snack foods, and other groceries. In the future, Marites would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Gay

texts.en:
Gay is 35 years old and married with four children.

Gay works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like school supplies, personal care products, home care products, canned goods and other groceries.

Gay has borrowed and paid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from buy-and-sell ready-to-wear.

Gay aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like school supplies, personal  care products, home care products and other groceries

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Gina works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell home care product business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  

Gina is borrowing PHP 9,500 through NWTF to  buy items to sell like soap powder, etc. for her buy-and-sell home care product business.

Gina has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like soap powder, etc.

loans.name: Irenglenda

texts.en:
Irenglenda is 36 years old and is married with three children. With three children in school, she works very hard to provide for her family.

Irenglenda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell, such as condiments, bread, home care products, and other groceries. She has been in this business for 4 years. In the future, Irenglenda would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, such as condiments, bread, home care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita lives in Talibon, Bohol. She engages in fishing. She catches and sells fish and crabs to the locals in the community. She is married with 5 children, ages 7-18 years old. Juanita is the one who sells the catch of her husband. She has been engaged in fishing for more than 10 years.

She is asking for a loan to buy fishing materials like crab nets and additional capital for a start-up buy-and-sell business.  

These tools will help her improve her yield and also it gives Juanita another source of income to start on. With the presence of these resources, Juanita's income will be augmented. Thus, she could now provide for the needs of her growing children, including healthy diets and better living conditions.

Juanita would like to manage her both business for the improvement of the family's status of living.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like crab nets and additional capital for buy and sell business

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures, like a rice retailing business.

Evangeline dreams that one day, she will be able to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to school and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
A $1,000 loan is offered to Marciana to help her improve her business. She has a kiosk where many people come to buy goods, and she plans to buy some additional supplies for her kiosk, such as plates, pans, spoons, buckets, racks, rice, etc.

She has been involved in business activities since 2002 and feels comfortable running her business because she can earn income each day. Running a business has made Marciana independent because she is responsible for herself and is able to help her family. She hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy plates, pans, spoons, buckets, racks, rice, etc.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet, age 44 and unmarried, runs a general store to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for 10 years, and she works very hard to cover her daily needs. 

She has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 10,000 through NWTF. She will use her loan funds to buy canned goods, cigarettes, home care products, and grocery items to offer for sale.

In the future, Janet would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, cigarettes, home care products, and grocery items to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy spare parts for her son's motorcycle spare parts business

loans.name: Janelle

texts.en:
Janelle is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Janelle is 34 years old and has two children who are in school.

Janelle has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

Janelle has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Janelle would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette is 40 years old and married with nine children. With all nine children in school, Janette works very hard to provide for them.

Janette runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, home care products, and other groceries.

Janette has been in this business for 12 years. 

In the future, Janette would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, home  care products, and other groceries

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose is 24 years old, married, and has one child who is in school. 

Mary Rose is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy feedsand other other supplies to raise her pigs.

Mary Rose has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mary Rose would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and other other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda runs a kiosk business to earn an income. She started this business on her own in 2009, and she reports that she is generating a good income from her sales. 

Florinda lives with her husband and family in Baucau.

She would like to replenish and enhance her inventory offerings in order to improve her business, so she requested a loan in the amount of $600. She will use her loan funds to buy grocery items such as noodles, coffee, sugar, salt, milk, and fish, as well as convenience items like cigarettes and slippers. 

In the future, she is thinking of running a bigger business, since she feels that she has enough experience to build a larger and more successful enterprise.

loans.use: to buy grocery items such as noodles, coffee, sugar, salt, milk, and fish, as well as convenience items like cigarettes and slippers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy spare parts for sewing machines for her husband's workshop.

loans.name: Baruch Group

texts.en:
Rachel developed an interest in arts and crafts when she was a young girl. Her aunt used to tell her stories of different cultures and the meaning of many symbols and crafts. As Rachel started mastering the meaning of art, symbols and their interpretation, she realized that there was more to everything than the stories she was told. Her curiosity drove her to learn more about the ways of her people and many other cultures in Africa and all over the world. When the right time came, Rachel’s family elders approved of her skills and passed on the family business to her.

Rachel sells different crafts and arts such as walking sticks, spears, stone sculptures, traditional musical instruments, traditional necklaces, earrings and many artifacts from various Southern African cultures. She has knowledge of the meaning and interpretation of different symbols crafted on the artifacts. She usually explains the meaning of the art or symbol on the object before selling it to her customers. Word of her experience and uniqueness of the art and crafts she sells has travelled far and many tourists are visiting her stall. 

She seeks funding to buy more crafts and stone sculptures from different areas of Southern Africa. She is also preparing her three young children to learn the ways of her people and at the same time keep the family business that has been running for generations profitable.

Rachel hopes that a loan from Kiva will help preserve the century-year-old tradition and her family business. Her group members run businesses that are different from Rachel’s business. Their group is called Baruch, and they hope that a Kiva loan will help them improve their businesses so that they can send their children to school.

loans.use: To increase her stock of stone sculptures to sell

loans.name: Key Of Life Group

texts.en:
In our modern society, with high costs of living, both husband and wife need to pool resources to provide a decent living for their children. This is the mindset that guides Esther, a married mother of three.  Esther is a tailor who specializes in bedding and school uniforms. Sometimes, she goes to neighboring Mozambique to sell bedding sheets, as there is a good market for them there. For the last nine years, the tailoring business has helped her complement her self-employed husband's income in providing for the needs of the family.

Key of Life is the name of the group that Esther and three other women in business formed. The women all had a common purpose - to source capital injections for their businesses. The group came to Thrive and attended lessons, gaining business knowledge and a group loan. Esther appreciates the training, as she feels that it has positively impacted her business. She is now able to plan and budget properly, and she puts aside savings for emergencies (as Key of Life saves as a group). With her Kiva loan, she is planning to buy rolls of material to sew sheets and uniforms in bulk for resale. The growth of her business will enable her to educate her children and help them attain great heights. In the future, Esther is looking forward to buying a residential stand.

loans.use: to buy rolls of material to expand her tailoring business.

loans.name: Leticia Nathaly

texts.es:
Leticia, requiere de más capital para comprar mesas, sillas y pagar la reparación de la plancha en que cocina, así se mantendrá atendiendo la venta de comida y pupusas funcionado.
Con el préstamo anterior se compró materia prima para elaborar la venta así mismo surtió el negocio con variedad de bebidas, las circunstancias de vida están mejorando.
texts.en: Leticia requires more capital in order to buy tables, chairs, and to pay for the repair to the flat-top on which she cooks so she will be able to continue working attending to the sales of food and pupusas . With the previous loan she bought raw material to make sales, additionally she supplied the business with a variety of drinks, the life circumstances are improving.

loans.use: Buying tables, chairs, and to pay for the repair of the flat top on which she cooks.

loans.name: Tweyambe Mutukula Women Group

texts.en:
Morine is a hardworking married woman with 6 children living in Bundibugyo Uganda. Her business is cocoa farming and selling on top of operating a bar where she sells local brew, she also has a stall in the market for fresh foods like tomatoes, cabbages for supplementary income. 

She is in need of a loan to pay for school fees for her five children and support her cocoa farm.  She has a great desire of accumulating more capital and becoming a prominent cocoa dealer in her area, although she complains of the difficulty of unpredictable weather changes and limited capital. 

Morine is a member of Tweyambe Mutukula Women Group where members guarantee each other to repay loans.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her five children and also to support her cocoa farming income

loans.name: Rusudan

texts.en:
Rusudan is 38 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and 2 children in Khelvachauri district. Rusudan is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, she has a plot of agricultural land, where she grows different kinds of trees and sells the harvest seasonally. In addition, she has a cow and sells cheese at a good price at local shops. 

Rusudan is very hard working woman and she does her best to make a better living conditions for her children. She wants to open a restaurant and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 5000 GEL. With the received credit she will purchase building materials, and the equipment for restaurant, such as chairs and tables. As the restaurant is built, Rusudan will work there hard and her husband will also help her to make their clients happy and satisfied with good meals and services.

loans.use: to build and completely equip a new restaurant

loans.name: Sail Through Group

texts.en:
Outside the Tobacco Sales Floor in Harare, Zimbabwe, a market place roars with activity as it awakens from its peaceful slumber. Vendors of all different types stand on either side of the road making the street narrow, forcing cars to move in single file. Large wagons decorated with a collage of vegetables and fruits are parked besides the street, and their owners stand beside them shouting out prices like auctioneers. From the deafening chaos in the market place, one of the voices that calls out to the customers is the voice of Lilian. She advertises her products by calling out to her customers, just as the other vendors in the market do.

She sell twine and other packaging materials to tobacco farmers, tobacco buyers and others who need to package their goods.  Lilian intelligently builds relationships with her customers and markets her products to encourage customer loyalty. She even supplies local companies with packaging materials such as orange and potato sacks. She has been able to secure huge orders from her customers in the market. Only a few of these orders have been met; this is because she lacks funding to buy the products in large quantities. 

Her friends have so far encouraged her to take a group loan from Thrive Microfinance. Their group is called Sail Through, which is made up of six hard working women. They hope that a Kiva loan will help their group expand their businesses and help Lilian to supply her customers.

loans.use: To expand her stock of twine, ropes and other packaging to sell to tobacco farmers.

loans.name: Seke 3 High Group

texts.en:
Vegetables and fruits are commodities that are bought daily. For one to get the freshest produce from the market, vendors have to wake up early. It is early morning that these determined women brave the early morning chill and go to get fresh fruits and vegetables at reasonable prices from the farmers. Puranat is usually a part of this early morning rush for fresh produce.

Puranat is a married mother of three young children. She has been a fruit and vegetable vendor for more than two years. After a need arose to give her business a capital injection, she came together with three other women to form Seke 3 High group. The group joined Thrive In May 2015 and attended training sessions. 

The group’s loan was approved after completing training. With her loan Puranat is planning to grow her vegetable stall and increase her profit levels. In future she is planning to buy a house for her family and give her children a decent education.

loans.use: To increase her stock to sell

loans.name: Tashaina Group

texts.en:
Don’t aim for success if you want it, just do what you love and believe in and it will come naturally –David Frost. This has been an inspirational quote for Liliosa.  She started off by crossing to South Africa to buy her own clothes because she loved fashion with a passion.  She then discovered that she could actually earn a living by selling fashionable clothes to other ladies in her community as they would admire her style.  

As business grew, she opened a flea market in town then expanded until she had to employ women for the other three flea market tables in the city. Competition in her area is so high that she has had to meet it by restocking more quantities of clothes which attracts consumers to her table. This led her to join Tashaina group with three other ladies who are also hardworking and passionate about their businesses. 

Liliosa's desire is to buy a motor vehicle so that movement to her four flea markets is made easier and efficiently. Hence with her Kiva loan she wants to restock more quantities of inventory for all her four flea markets.

loans.use: To increase her stock of goods for sale.

loans.name: Greenlight Group

texts.en:
As dusk sets in, it paves the way for the dark, cold June night, and this is when Juliet’s bus arrives at the Beitbridge border post. She will arrive in Johannesburg, South Africa, in the early hours of the next morning and will sleep off the rest of the morning at a service station. In the morning, Juliet will navigate through a series of shops, buying groceries for resale back in Zimbabwe. 

Back home in Harare, her daughter, Tapiwa, skips two days of school in order to run her mother’s business while she is absent. Their family of seven people survives on Juliet’s business selling groceries and so they cannot afford to miss a day’s earnings. Just outside her home, Juliet has a makeshift wooden structure tuck-shop where she sells groceries to the local people. There are not many shops around the area where she stays, so her neighbours rely on tuck shops such as Juliet’s, to buy almost all breakfast groceries, and other household items such as toilet tissue and mealie meal. 

Juliet and her friends are part of a group called Greenlight. They have been taking loans from Thrive Microfinance. With her 3rd loan, Juliet hopes to start buying electric appliances such as refrigerators and groceries to supply her customers. They hope that a loan from Kiva will help them move away from selling from their gates and to open their own shops.

loans.use: To start selling electrical goods through her tuck shop.

loans.name: Women Of Land Group

texts.en:
Tandiwe is a 30-year-old mother who wakes up early in the morning to cook for her three children before going to a nearby market to open her small stall where she sells clothes. She basically runs a business selling clothes from South Africa. She also makes a little extra cash by selling cosmetics, and clothing accessories from a clothing brand distributer based in South Africa. Tandiwe builds relationships with her customers by introducing them to her products and recruiting them as distributors. This offers her an opportunity to earn extra income through royalties paid by the company.

Her family has been surviving on her business and she has been able to feed, clothe, and send her children to school with profits from her business. She has been saving money with her fellow group members and currently plans to set up a fund for her children’s future education. 

Tandiwe and her group called Women of Land are taking a second loan from Thrive Microfinance. They are hoping that a loan from Kiva will help Tandiwe buy her stock of goods in large quantities and reduce the number of times she crosses the border to South Africa.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothes, cosmetics & other products to sell.

loans.name: Real Time Group

texts.en:
In the neighbourhood of Dzivarasekwa extension you find women trading in different fields, selling different wares in a bid to survive in this tough economic climate. There are women who trade outside the local shops, some walk around the streets, and some operate from home. Patricia is one of those who operates a business from home.

After realizing that tenants to occupy her small room where not easy to come by, Patricia decided to turn it into a mini-saloon business. She plaits and retouches women’s hair from her home-based saloon, as well as sells second-hand clothing to people from her neighbourhood. Patricia and three other like-minded women came together to form Real Time Business Group. The group is comprised of women in small businesses who all had a wish to grow their businesses. Patricia and her group members came to Thrive and benefitted a lot from the training that they attended.

Her loan will help her get more clothes to sell and buy more stuff for her saloon to attract more customers.

loans.use: To increase the stock she can sell through her small hairdressing salon.

loans.name: Eliana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal QORICHASKAS, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco.
La socia Eliana  continua trabajando en su consultorio dental, la socia es odontóloga de profesión, la socia Eliana se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas, la socia es una persona responsable, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia Eliana solicita el crédito para la compra de materiales como masillas entre otros.
texts.en:
Eliana is a member of the QORICHASKAS communal bank, which is located in the province of Cusco. 

Eliana continues working in her dental office. She is a dentist by trade. She is grateful for the loan offered and promises to follow through with the payment schedule. She is a responsible person and wants to keep working in order to continue supporting her family. 

Eliana is requesting the loan in order to purchase materials such as dental putty, among others.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as dental putty, among others.

loans.name: Señor De Los Milagros De Chimpahuaylla Group

texts.es:
La socia Dora Delia, ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de los Milagros de Chimpahuaylla” de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú.
La socia Dora Delia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose a enseñar en uno de los colegios de la ciudad, la socia lleva años dedicándose a trabajar el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su trabajo, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
 La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de materiales como papeles, plumones entre otros.
Los socios se sienten  agradecidos  por el crédito otorgado y se comprometen a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
The member, Dora Delia, belongs to the communal bank "Señor de los Milagros de Chimpahuaylla [Lord of Miracles of Chimpahuaylla]" of Cusco - Peru.

The member, Dora Delia, alternates her daily activities  and  teaches at one of the schools in the city.  This member has spent years at this job at which she does quite well thanks to the effort she puts into the work that she does each and every day.  

The member wishes to be able to continue working so as to continue supporting her family.

The member is requesting a loan to purchase materials such as paper, markers and more.

All members feel grateful for the loan granted and are committed to fulfill their established quotas.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as paper, markers and more.

loans.name: Lucero Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LUCERO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Clorinda continua con su negocio de carpintería, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de madera entre otros.
Los otros socios  se dedican al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, venta de cereales, trabajadores de empresa privada.
Las socias que salen en la foto adjunta pidieron permiso para llegar tarde a la reunión por motivos de trabajo.
texts.en:
These people belong to the “Lucero" communal bank. This bank is located in the Cusco district, which belongs to the Cusco province and department.

One member is Clorinda.  She continues with her carpentry business.  She has been doing her business for a good while now, and it is going well for her thanks to the effort that she puts into it each day.  She is thankful to the people who are part of her dream in this way and is committed to making her payments according to the established schedule.  She wants to be able to keep working in order to support her family in this way.

She is asking for this loan in order to buy wood, among other items.

The other members work in a convenience store, selling cereals, and working for a private company.

The members who are in the attached photo asked permission to arrive late to the meeting due to their work.

loans.use: to buy wood, among other items.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with five children.

She earns a living by raising goats in the Philippines and is borrowing PHP 8,000 through NWTF in order to buy feed and other supplies to raise her livestock.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Rosalia dreams that one day, she will be able to save enough money to expand her business

loans.use: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her livestock.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina, age 35, runs a general store to earn an income.  She has been operating her business for two years and also earns an income from food vending. She has one child, and she works hard to provide for her family. 

She requested a loan in the amount of PhP 10,000 through NWTF. She will use her loan funds to buy items such as snack foods, personal care products, home care products, and groceries to offer for sale in her store. This will be her second loan. She repaid her first loan successfully.
 
Lina aspires to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items such as snack foods, personal care products, home care products, and groceries to offer for sale

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza, age 41, buys and sells rice to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for six years and is a very hard-working entrepreneur. She and her husband have four children, three of whom attend school.

Liza requested a loan in the amount of PhP 10,000 through NWTF. She will use her loan funds to buy sacks of rice to offer for sale.

In the future, Liza would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to offer for sale

loans.name: Luis Alfredo

texts.es:
Luis, está satisfecho con las cosechas obtenidas de maíz y frijol, lo cual ha sido posible con la ayuda del financiamiento anterior, su familia se mantiene y puede cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, continua siendo soltero.
Está solicitando un nuevo crédito para seguir trabajando en la agricultura, comprara básicamente abono, semilla, herbicidas e insecticidas para la nueva siembra de granos básicos, con dichos materiales sus cultivos tendrán un mejor desarrollo.
texts.en:
Luis is satisfied with the harvests obtained of corn and beans, which have been possible with the help of the previous financing, he supports his family and can cover the basic needs of his home, he continues being single.
He is applying for a new loan to continue working in agriculture, he will basically buy fertilizer, seeds, herbicides, and insecticides for the new sowing of basic grains, with said materials his crops will have  better growth.

loans.use: He will buy basically fertilizer, seeds, herbicides and insecticides for the new sowing of basic grains.

loans.name: Andrian

texts.en:
Adrian, 31, is married with one child and runs a small farm to support his family. He decided to start this business about 8 years ago after he was given a cow as a wedding present ! He was able to take the cow and the following offspring and create a small farm. Not long after this he was able to purchase a house and a barn outside of the town to grow his business. The farm currently consists of 4 dairy cows, 5 beef cattle and 40 pigs. 

The dairy farm has become the core business of his family and the selling of the milk and other milk products is the main source of income for his family. The selling of animals for meat or breeding is another source of income for the business. 

Adrian wants to expand his business and to do so he will need to purchase more animals. Increasing the size of the farm will enable the family to increase their income and will also create several jobs for the local village.

loans.use: To pay for the purchase of more cows to add to his dairy farm, for income for him and his family and will also create jobs locally

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal QORICHASKAS, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco.
La socia Carmen continua con su negocio de venta de granos secos como maíz, trigo entre otros, la socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas, la socia continua vendiendo su mercadería a sus clientes que le solicitan, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de trigo entre otros.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the communal bank QORICHASKAS, the bank is located in the province Cusco. Carmen continues with her business selling dry grains such as corn and wheat among others, she is grateful for the loan granted and promises to complete her established payments, she continues selling her merchandise to her clients that request them, she wishes to be able to continue working this way in order to continue supporting her family.
She is applying for the loan in order to buy wheat among other grains.

loans.use: For the purchase of wheat among others.

loans.name: Kyamazima Tweyimukye Group

texts.en: Tom is a member of Kyamazima Tweyimukye where members guarantee each other to get a loan instead of pledging a security. He is a farmer growing tea and rearing cattle to get income. He is faced with a challenge of bad weather that hinders expansion of his agriculture activities. Besides that, he has hopes of building a permanent house and expanding his farm. He has asked for a loan to invest in tea growing and clearing more land for farming.

loans.use: to invest in tea growing and clearing more land for farming.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel, age 28, raises pigs to earn her living. Her husband works as a driver, and they combine their incomes to support themselves and their child. 

Because Maricel's primary goal is to offer her family a good living, she decided to request a loan in order to purchase additional feed for her pigs. This will allow her piggery to produce pigs of higher quality that will sell well at the market, bringing Maricel a better income.

Her plan for the future is to expand her business so that it will uplift her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her pigs

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma, who is 44 years old  and a married woman, lives in Tskaltubo district. She has 2 school-aged daughters and husband, who lives abroad and transfers some money for his family's welfare. However the family finds it hard to cope with their financial difficulties and make better living condition. Irma was unable to start any stable job, so she decided to be involved in her own business and generate her own income. 

She couldn’t receive a loan from the local financial institutions, because of their requirements to have business experience or stable revenue, until the Start Up program began which is a joint product of Kiva and Credo. The program allows poor people like Irma to get a chance for starting or re-starting business. 

Irma has experience of trading activities and is eager to re-start her business and trade in her community with various kind clothing and bed linens. She will purchase products at wholesale prices and then resell for a profit.
 
Irma is very enthusiastic and hard working person with a great desire to ensure her children with good education for progressing in life.  This credit will be a great support for the family. Irma is thankful to Kiva lenders for giving her a chance to generate her own income.

loans.use: To start trading with clothing and bed linens to support her family

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy mulch and cow dung to boost his output

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase materials to build a bathroom on the patio of her home.

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel tiene 40 años de edad, es soltera, es muy conocida en su comunidad por su labor de venta de pan en su mototaxi. Ella vive en casa familiar de su madre, es una persona con buenas referencias por parte de sus vecinos, su comunidad está ubicada en la provincia de Chiclayo, departamento de Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú, con un clima cálido, su población es muy agradable y se dedica al comercio, agricultura y ganadería.

Raquel se dedica a la venta de pan en su mototaxi, desde hace más de 06 años aproximadamente, además da en alquiler otra mototaxi de su propiedad, ella necesita el préstamo para invertir en capital de trabajo para incrementar su negocio con la venta de soya, avena, y tamales, para de esta manera hacer crecer su negocio y asi incrementar sus ingresos y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Raquel is 40 years old and single. She is well-known in her community for her work selling bread from her motorcycle taxi. She lives in the family home with her mother and is a person with good references from her neighbors. Her community is located in Chiclayo province, Lambayeque department, on the northern coast of Peru, with a warm climate. Its population is very friendly and works in trade, agriculture and raising animals. 

Raquel has worked selling bread from her motorcycle taxi for more than approximately 6 years. In addition, she rents out another motorcycle taxi that is her property. She needs the loan to invest in working capital to expand her sales of soy, oats and tamales, so that she can grow her business and in this way increase her income with the end of improving her quality of life and that of her family.

loans.use: to invest in working capital to expand his business selling soy, oats and tamales.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida, age 63, runs a sari-sari store to earn her living. In the Philippines, sari-sari stores are everywhere. Sari-sari is a Filipino term for variety, and these stores sell a variety of products such as biscuits, candies, canned goods, noodles, toiletries, and many other items that are needed in an individual’s daily living. This is considered as one of the most common businesses built by ordinary people since it provides needed commodities for people.

Adelaida and her husband have six children. The family lives in Santa Barbara, Iloilo. The income from Adelaida's store helps to provide for her family's daily needs. However, due to competition in this kind of business, her income is unstable. Hence, she decided to venture into hog raising a year ago to bring in additional profit. 

The initial capital for hog raising is high, just as it was for her sari-sari store. Adelaida built a small pig pen and bought piglets and feed. The return of investment is quite positive in this venture, but it will take several months before she can enjoy it. 

As of now, she needs to sustain the requirements of her small piggery, as well as her variety store. This is why she is requesting a PhP 20,000 loan. She will use her loan funds partly to buy additional piglets, feed, and vitamins, and partly to buy more products to offer for sale in her variety store. 

In due time, she hopes that her two enterprises will progress and will give her family a comfortable life. 

Adelaida meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: partly to buy additional piglets, feed, and vitamins, and partly to buy more products to offer for sale in her variety store

loans.name: Berlin

texts.en: Berlin is 43 years old, married and the mother of two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur who runs a dried-fish vending business in the Philippines. Berlin is seeking a PHP 10,000 loan from NWTF to buy more fish to sell. She successfully paid back her previous loan and will use the new one to further build her business. Berlin has been in her current line of work for 13 years, and would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Alliance Group

texts.fr: Hamidou est commerçante, propriétaire d’une boutique remplie de divers produits manufacturés dans le bidonville depuis 6 ans, qui s’entraide avec son mari, membre du groupe de crédits «Alliance», cliente de l’IMF Hekima, âgée de 40 ans, mère de 6 enfants dont 4 scolarisés et 2 sont gosses. Elle va acheter des biscuits, huiles, piles, savons, etc. Ainsi, elle souhaite accroitre son capital, scolariser et nourrir ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie Hekima pour le soutien apporté aux entrepreneurs non bancables.
texts.en:
Hamidou is a shopkeeper who for six years has owned a general store in the slum area, a shop filled with various manufactured goods. She and her husband work together. She is a member of the loan group Alliance, a client of Hekima, aged 40, mother of six children of whom four are in school and two are still too young for school. 

Hamidou is going to buy cookies, oil, batteries, soap, etc. In this way, she hopes to grow her capital, keep her kids in school, and feed them. In conclusion, she thanks Hekima for the support it brings to entrepreneurs who are not served by the conventional banking system.

loans.use: to buy cookies, oil, batteries, soap, etc

loans.name: Severo

texts.en:
Severo is a 44 year old hardworking married man with 6 children who lives in Masindi, Uganda. He sells sodas and beers in a depot. He opened up a retail shop, goat rearing and a video show hall to generate more income for his business. However he faces a challenge of inadequate capital to sustain all these businesses. 

Severo desires to construct more houses for renting so as to increase his income. He is requesting a loan to buy materials like iron sheets for completing his house.

loans.use: to buy materials like iron sheets for completing his rental houses for a more stable income.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is a 34 year old married male with 4 children. He lives in the town of Masindi-Uganda. He has a vehicle that deals in the transportation business. He desires to build his own house. William started the business to sustain himself. Poor roads affect his business and this leads to constant mechanical breakdowns plus repairs hence less earnings. 

He is requesting a loan to buy another vehicle for transport business.

loans.use: to buy another vehicle for his taxi and transport business.

loans.name: Najax Group

texts.en:
Najah is a 28 year old married man and the father of one daughter.  He owns a workshop which makes metal doors and gates and also he makes water tanks. Najah was working in another workshop since 2001, but in 2007 he started his own business.

Najax wants to extend his business operations, so for that reason he applied to Kaaba MFI for a loan of $1000. Najah is the leader of Najah group, as can see from the photo Najah is the one sitting in the middle of the group photo and raising his hand. This group consist of ten members two men and eight women. Each group member has separate business and they all the need to expand their existing small and medium businesses.

loans.use: To expand his workshop's production of metal doors, gates and water tanks

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a 35 years-old-woman. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, with her one son and two daughters and her children are in school. Her husband has been running his own business of clothing selling for 6 years and is responsible to feed the entire family and manage the household. 

Her husband needs to purchase different types of clothing in bulk for reselling purpose, but due to insufficient financial means he is unable to purchase these clothes. Therefore Sonia is applying for Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. So that she can assist her husband to purchase these clothes in bulk for his business. Her husband can also increase the size of his business and earn maximum profit with the help of this loan amount. 

Sonia is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her husband's clothing business

loans.name: Las Mescladitas Group

texts.es:
Guedy es una mujer de 30 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene 2 hijos de 2 y 7 años, y su negocio es la venta de artículos de ferretería.
Ella es buena madre, constante, paciente, amable, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla en la zona ‘plan 3000’ ubicado a 12 kilómetros de la ciudad, caracterizada por acoger a los sobrevivientes del desborde del río en el año 1983, los migrantes que llegaron desde las provincias y el resto del país se fueron asentando en esa zona que hoy tiene más del 20% del total de la población, cuenta con servicios básicos como; salud y educación, Es un distrito pobre. De clima cálido sub tropical con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 21-35 grados centígrados.
Guedy es de tez trigueña, ojos pardos, cabello castaño largo lo usa amarrado por detrás, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (la tercera de la derecha, viste chompa marrón y pantalón jean celeste). Su vida la realiza junto a su pareja que trabaja en el comercio y con sus hijos; el mayor estudia en la escuela y el menor aún no se encuentra en edad escolar, viven en un cuarto propio construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Su anhelo de superación la impulsó a liderar una banca de personas con negocios como; puesto de venta de comida, venta de chompas, materiales de construcción, tejido de ropa de bebe, venta de papas fritas, venta de ropa deportiva y tienda de barrio, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de artículos de ferretería como; tornillos, alambres, martillos, cierra, y otros, actividad que realiza en su puesto de venta fijo al aire libre de lunes a viernes durante el día, “la ferretería de algún modo es un mundo de hombres y para una mujer cuesta abrirse paso…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con ventas constantes, la desventaja es la falta de materiales de ferretería. Su sueño es administrar un negocio estable, ella desea abastecer su ferretería con materiales de todo tipo para mejorar su variedad y establecer su negocio. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 2 años que desarrolla esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Guedy solicita un préstamo para abastecer su ferretería con mercadería de alta rotación para establecer su negocio.
texts.en:
Guedy, 30, lives with her partner.  She has two children, ages 2 and 7, and her business is selling hardware.  She's dependable, patient, friendly, responsible, and very hardworking, and she's a good mother.

She works in the Plan 3000 area located 12 kilometers from the city, an area known for welcoming survivors of the 1983 flood.  The migrants who arrived from the provinces and elsewhere in the country settled in that area (now more than 20% of the population), which has basic services such as health and education.  It's a poor area of subtropical climate with a temperature that varies between 21 and 35 degrees centigrade during the day.

Guedy is short, dark, and robust, with brown eyes and long brown hair that she wears tied back.  (She's the third from the right, wearing a brown sweater and blue jeans.)  Her native language is Guaraní, which she speaks with her family; she knows Spanish through general knowledge and speaks it for business.

She lives with her partner, who works as a vendor, and with her children.  The oldest child attends school and the youngest is not yet old enough for school.  They live in their own home built of brick and cement with a corrugated metal roof and a brick floor; they have potable water, electricity, and gas.
